Comment: Andrew Leach's unconvincing response to criticism of Justin Trudeau's climate policies by David Suzuki and Bill McKibben is notable for what it omits. It includes no discussion of the 1.5 - 2 ˚C targets agreed in Paris, what sort of global emission reductions are necessary to meet them, and the consequences of warming left unchecked. It similarly ignores Canada's excessive historical and per capita emissions, and the political and moral necessity for "contraction and convergence" in which countries with the highest emissions cut fastest and deepest. He also ignores the cost of locking in high-carbon infrastructure like pipelines which are economically intended to run for decades, but will need to be shut down early as part of concerted global climate action. Leach's "take what you can get, we could do less" message is an unsatisfactory response to the urgent challenge of climate change, and its not one that Trudeau or Canadians should accept.

Milan Ilnyckyj
Toronto

However, it does not follow that because there are a lot of Jewish people in Hollywood, a film made by a non-Jew about the Holocaust would (or wouldn't) be a form of appropriation. That is a non-sequitur that itself borders on racist, though I don't think you meant it that way. Comment: I guess I'll have to start putting the source in again, especially for poor Motley. The 30% loss of cyclists in Eugene since 2009 comes from the US Census American Community Survey. It tracks mode of commuting, a reasonable stand-in for overall cycling. In 2009, 10.8% of all workers living in Eugene used their bikes to commute. In 2015, the latest year of data, that had fallen to 7.6%.

It's a little difficult to get to the data if you haven't played with it before, so here's some help. Go to American Fact finder, scroll down to American Community Survey, click on "get data". In the new page, click on geographies, select "place", choose your state, select the city you're interested in and then close the geography window. In the data choices, click on "commuting characteristics by sex" (one year data, not 5-year smoothed) and you will see the various modes broken down by numbers, percentages and genders. To see other years, select one from the list on the left.

Comment: The pundits have been out in force on this issue but I do not see any competent comments.

When the US opts out of NAFTA it must give its partners six months notice. The US government must then change some trade laws to support its actions. This process may take longer than six months if recent Congressional gridlock is anything to go by. Legislative changes may extend the transition period in order to mitigate the disruption to some states.

Furthermore, if the US opts out of NAFTA we in theory fall  back onto the FTA which the US may not want to change. If they do there will likely be another negotiating process that is unlikely to begin until NAFTA is officially dead.

Overall, the affects of the demise of NAFTA could play out over several years, giving companies lots of time to adjust.

The stuffed shirts giving opinions on this issue seem ignorant of all this or are ignoring it in order to make broad brush statements that the sky is falling.

Comment: The focus is now on the budget and all of our eyes are on it. However, it is a distraction from the big elephant stomping on our budget because Alaska does not take enough Royalty from their oil. It is now 12.5% under existing legacy oil and gas leases, therefore, the oil and gas industry own 87.5% of all of the oil under the ground under those legacy leases. 

All legal and contractually correct and there is no way to change Alaska's Royalty take. The only way to claw back more money out of the 87.5% that the oil and gas industry now owns, is to get them with increased severance taxes, reduce or get rid of generous tax credits that they now enjoy, and any other tax measures that can be developed to increase our oil and gas take.

All oil and gas leases, going forward from today, should be changed from 12.5% to no less that 50% by the legislature with an immediate effective date. 

This would mean that the Division of Oil and Gas would not be able to issue a lease for 12.5% ever again.

Comment: The first thing you should know, is the purpose behind why you are in the gym in the first place.  Is it to lose weight?  Is it to make your body sculpted (to impress the opposite sex)?  To give you more energy?  Is it to stretch out your muscles and joints in order to minimize the pains of growing older?  

There are different ways to exercise.  There's cardio-vascular exercises for energy and weight loss, and there's weight training which can be used for building strength (heavy weights, few repetitions), body sculpting (medium weights, many repetitons), muscular endurance (light weights, continuous movement).  There are movements which stretch muscles and joints (range of motion goes to the body limits) and there are power movements which may be in a narrow range of motion (like half squats with a heavy weight).  

And there are different muscle groups on which to focus.  For example, you might focus on abdominals, lower back, and hips if you have problems with your lower back.

Comment: I don't understand his calculation of $125K.

There is the cost of tuition, living, expenses.  Let's say this adds up to $50K
Then there is the opportunity cost of after tax income.  Let's say this adds up to $75K.

If he were working (did not do the MBA) then he would not have the MBA expense so he is making $75K
But  if he  is in the MBA program (spending $50K) he would not be able to work.  

Therefore, while I take his comment about the opportunity cost of not working, this doesn't add up, because he is either working or not (+$75K or nothing).  He is either enrolled in the MBA (-$50K or nothing).  But he can't do both.  If he is working he is not in MBA.  If he is in the MBA he is not working.  So I don't think you can say you spent $50K but also gave up $75K because if you had been working you would not have been spending the $50K.

What do I know, I am not an MBA, just a scientist.

Comment: There is a fair bit of economic theory to back up the notion that larger companies will be better able to absorb changes to minimum wage than smaller companies.

First off you have the obvious: If you only have 2 employees and you need to raise the wage of 1 of them it will have a much bigger impact than a company that has thousands of employees and only needs to raise the wage of 10% of them.

Large companies also have the economies of scale to automate away jobs.  Automation often involves a substantial capital investment up front to reduce operating expenses, a difficult proposition for a small company but much easier for big companies.

There is also geographic distribution.  If Ontario raises minimum wage it only affects maybe 1% of Walmart stores worldwide but it will impact 100% of many small businesses that only operate 1 location if it is  in Ontario.

There was a public hearing on this in February. Then a special town hall meeting March 21. And finally the council vote on March 28. All these meetings were pre-announced. If there had actually been any real opposition, people would have attended the meetings, started writing letters to the Kitsap Daily News, and organized an opposition by now.

What's tricky is translating boardings into unique passengers.  The average rider would make at least 2 boardings per day (round trip commute). But I would guess the lion's share are people that make between 2 and 4 boardings per day, so let's say 3 for a reasonable average.  329k / 2.92M / 3 = 3.8%.

Comment: As a long proponent of the gas to liquids technology, a GTL plant on the North Slope can do several important things for Alaska.  A portion, up to 50% of the output of a GTL plant can be what is commonly referred to as a diluent.  In other parts of the world a diluent is used to extract heavy oil and in several parts of the Canadian tar sands programs a diluent is used to blend with their heavy crude to transport the heavy oil in pipelines.  We can do the same thing on the North Slope with a diluent to help extract this heavy oil and assist in the transport down TAPS to Valdez.  The diluent is recovered at the refinery and turned into valuable products.  Diluent will have a higher value than the heavy crude oil.  So the natural gas already on the North Slope can be turned into valuable liquids which can be shipped down TAPS to market and it can also be used to create a diluent to help extract and transport this heavy oil.  GTL's weren't available 20 years ago they are today.

Essentially, plants in the desert are using far less of the limited water the area receives and are slowly encroaching in deserts like the Sahara and in Australia where the research was conducted.

We're only getting increased desertification in areas affected by dramatic human deforestation which has little if anything to do with climate but caused by the forestry industry or locals depleting limited trees for fuel or shelter.

Comment: I worked with acting-out children and youth for almost 40 years. mostly as a special education teacher. Special programs are expensive. Their effectiveness depends on many variables, not the least of which is the kid's willingness to change. Openness is often a matter of timing: a kid who is defiant and subversive may encounter a 'reality check' that suddenly makes him open to improvement. 

It's helpful when kids realize that there is a spectrum of services and facilities for people (both adults and children) who cannot manage in the regular system and that this spectrum involves increased/decreased freedoms. Some kids are determined to test that system so it's important to have effective responses available when & where they are needed. 

Everyone loses when an acting-out child is in an ineffective milieu (home, classroom, residential facility). Staff & parents get burnt out, peers are negatively affected and the child/youth's misbehaviour is encouraged, his attitudes harden, etc.

Section 92(10(a) empowers a province to legislate over various local works and undertakings:

            "(a) Lines of Steam or other Ships, Railways, Roads, Telegraphs, and other Works and Undertakings         connecting the Province with any other or others of the Provinces, or extending beyond the Limits of the Province

Pipelines are not mentioned.      

The federal Parliament  can, however, declare a work to be for the general benefit of Canada or three or more provinces under section 92(10(c):

           "(c) Such Works as, although wholly situate within the Province, are before or after their Execution declared by the Parliament of Canada to be for the general Advantage of Canada or for the Advantage of Three or more of the Provinces.

In the absence of a federal declaration, B.C. is within its rights to lay down condition for the expansion of this pipeline.

Comment: Outsider,  The Nation's Report Card, known as the NAEP test, was highest when there were only 3 or 4 short standardized tests in a student's entire k-12 career.  But now kids take 120 standardized tests, some over 11 hours long.

It's simple math that increased testing reduces learning time and costs more.  We now spend 35x more on standardized testing than just 7 years ago.  

The result?  There isn't enough money for science labs, civics, health, PE, music, art, shop, nurses or the counselors needed to advise students on college and career choices.  Further, outside measures like the NAEP haven't budged.  

We only need a few, high quality standardized tests to compare students, classes and schools.  Meanwhile, multiple studies show unit tests are far more relevant to learning, and grades are the ultimate predictor of college or career success.

Overtesting isn't working and it's not worth it.

Comment: You know, my father ran the research division of a multinational corporation for many years. Hardly any research is being done in the US that does not have direct corporate funding  --  and I worry about the impact of that change.

Comment: A mass transit system will seldom be self-supporting.  Were it to be, the cost of using it would be so prohibitive that it would cease to exist.  It will be used more by some citizens than others....and, yes, some won't use it at all.  The same can be said of libraries, parks, walking and riding paths, city or county owned sports/entertainment venues, citizen recreational facilities,  and all other public facilities  Publicly owned mass transit systems directly serve the riders and, additionally, serve the rest of the community by decreasing private vehicular traffic and the resulting congestion and pollution.  

As I said, were we to choose to fund such facilities and services only through direct user-fees, there would be  no such facilities and services.

That said, it should be the city or special districts responsibility to convince the taxpayers that any tax or increase in tax is merited.  To give LTD unilateral authority to imcrease a tax or impose a new one is not justified.

Comment: Younglai writes: “Canadian employers added 396,800 full-time positions from October of last year, marking the strongest job growth since the turn of the century.” This is true; you have to go to March 2000, when 417,800 full-time jobs were created to find a better month by this metric. However, if one looks instead at the annual growth rate in full-time jobs, it was 2.7% in October 2017, less than July 2011 (2.8%) and not substantially higher than August or September 2011 (2.6%). As for the headline about a new record being set for full-time jobs, that happens all the time with these data; September was a record month too. Shouldn’t the headline have been “Unemployment rate rises in October”?
